data.title: Zine El Abidine Ben Ali obituary
data.meta_description: Despite ruling Tunisia for almost a quarter of a century, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali was little known to the wider world until January 2011. That was when he became the first autocrat to be toppled by the popular uprising known as the Arab Spring. His flight from the presidential palace in Tunis
data.text:
Despite ruling Tunisia for almost a quarter of a century, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali was little known to the wider world until January 2011. That was when he became the first autocrat to be toppled by the popular uprising known as the Arab Spring.

His flight from the presidential palace in Tunis was characterised as a “Ceausescu moment” in a reference to the Romanian dictator’s hurried exit in Bucharest more than two decades earlier. Ben Ali was no match for Ceausescu in the brutality stakes, but he shared the same conviction about his seemingly unshakeable grip on power, and the same bewilderment at losing it.

Ben Ali had seized power in a bloodless coup in November 1987, overthrowing the north African country’s founding father
